block.p: 1,000 Feared Lost as Ferry Sinks Near Egyptian Coast A ferry carrying more than 1,400 people, mostly Egyptian laborers returning from Saudi Arabia, sank about 40 miles off the coast of Egypt, and by late evening, only about 300 people had been rescued and hopes for others was fading. Egyptian officials said most of the survivors had escaped on lifeboats, with a few plucked directly from the waters of the Red Sea.

Nuclear Board Delays Iran Vote The International Atomic Energy Agency put off a vote on a resolution on Iran's nuclear program because of American opposition to a clause indirectly criticizing Israel's nuclear weapons status, according to diplomats. But later a compromise seemed to have been worked out.

U.S. Defends Cartoon Protests As anger continued to spread in the Muslim world over caricatures of the Muhammad published in European newspapers, the White House said it understood ''why Muslims would find these images offensive.''

U.N. to Send Troops to Sudan The United Nations Security Council, acknowledging the failure of the current strategy for ending the carnage in Darfur, Sudan, agreed to deploy thousands of peacekeepers to the troubled province.
Mexico Closes Medical Clinic Mexican health officials shut down an alternative medicine clinic where Coretta Scott King died this week, saying the doctors there were using unproven treatments.
Taliban and Afghan Police Clash Heavy fighting in Afghanistan between Taliban fighters and Afghan police forces left three policemen and at least six Taliban militants dead, Afghan officials said.

Bush Budget to Propose Major Savings in Medicare In his budget next week, President Bush will propose substantial savings in Medicare, stepping up his efforts to rein in the growing costs of social insurance programs, administration officials and others said.
5 Alabama Churches Burned Suspicious fires destroyed three small churches and damaged two others in central Alabama, officials said.

Court Limits Records Search The Kansas Supreme Court restricted an unusual and divisive investigation by state Attorney General Phill Kline into illegal abortions and child rape, ruling that the names and personal information of 90 women and girls must be removed from the records he is seeking from two abortion clinics.

Papers in Leak Case Released Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff told prosecutors that Mr. Cheney had informed him ''in an off sort of curiosity sort of fashion'' in mid-June 2003 about the identity of the C.I.A. official at the heart of the leak case, according to a formerly secret legal opinion.

NASA Chief Calls for Openness A week after NASA's top climate scientist complained that the space agency's public-affairs office was trying to silence his statements on global warming, Administrator Michael D. Griffin issued a terse statement calling for ''scientific openness'' throughout the agency.

Child Deaths Cast Glare On Child Welfare System In 1999 the New York City child welfare system started to lean toward a practice of keeping troubled families intact, with frequent monitoring by caseworkers, and using foster care only as a last resort. But a string of deaths of children left in their homes has put the city on the defensive about its family preservation policies.

Minorities Plagued by AIDS In the decade since effective drug treatments for AIDS have slashed death rates across the country, black New Yorkers continue to fall ill -- and die from -- the disease at startling rates, according to new data from the city health department.

Knicks Add Offense in Rose Isiah Thomas, not idling amid the turmoil swirling around him, made a trade typical of his tenure as Knicks president by taking on an expensive player slightly past his prime, but acquiring a first-round draft pick in the process. Before the Knicks' 104-90 loss to the Raptors in Toronto, Thomas shipped the veteran power forward Antonio Davis to the Raptors for small forward Jalen Rose and a draft pick.
Henry S. Coleman An administrator at Columbia University for a third of a century, including a memorable 24 hours in 1968 when student demonstrators took him hostage, he was 79.

Internet Privacy Questioned Despite the promise to protect the privacy of their users, companies that provide Internet services are routinely fulfilling requests to provide user information to criminal investigators and lawyers fighting civil cases.

Unemployment Rate Falls In one of the strongest job reports since the start of the recovery in late 2001, the government reported that the unemployment rate fell to 4.7 percent, its lowest level in more than four years. The nation's employers hired workers in nearly every industry.
U.S. Seeks Pension Plan The federal government announced that it filed suit to seize the pension plan of the bankrupt WCI Steel from its parent corporation, the Renco Group.
Editorials: Mardi Gras medical; tax talk goes Orwellian; the high cost of public information; a turning point for New York courts.
